TITLE: A Cyberattack Illuminates the Shaky State of Student Privacy
SUMMARY: At a moment when education technology firms are stockpiling sensitive information on millions of school children, safeguards for student data have broken down.

TITLE: United Auto Workers Seek to Shed a Legacy of Corruption
SUMMARY: After his predecessors’ imprisonment, the union’s president is being challenged for re-election in the first direct vote by its membership.

TITLE: Will the Biggest Publisher in the United States Get Even Bigger?
SUMMARY: The Biden administration is suing to block Penguin Random House from buying Simon & Schuster. A United States District Court will decide if the sale can proceed.

TITLE: Alex Jones Puts Company Behind Infowars Empire Into Bankruptcy
SUMMARY: The move came as he faces a judgment of as much as $150 million for defaming Sandy Hook families.

TITLE: Gen Z Knows What It Wants From Employers. And Employers Want Them.
SUMMARY: To tap into the creativity of younger workers, and to offset a labor shortage, companies are offering four-day weeks, club memberships and work-from-anywhere flexibility.

TITLE: This Week in Business: Recession Fears
SUMMARY: Meta reported its first-ever revenue decline. The Fed agreed on another supersize rate increase. And oil company earnings are booming.

TITLE: Banana Boat Recalls Hair and Scalp Sunscreen Over Low Levels of Carcinogen
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration said consumers should immediately stop using the product if it came from any of the three batches recalled.

TITLE: Banana Boat Recalls Sunscreen Over Low Levels of Carcinogen
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration said consumers should immediately stop using the product if it came from any of the three batches recalled.

TITLE: How Some Parents Changed Their Politics in the Pandemic
SUMMARY: They were once Democrats and Republicans. But fears for their children in the pandemic transformed their thinking, turning them into single-issue voters for November’s midterms.

TITLE: What Drives the Price of Wheat, Beyond War in Ukraine
SUMMARY: The price has fallen sharply from its peak after one major producer, Russia, invaded another, Ukraine. But that hasn’t ended fears of a global hunger crisis.

TITLE: After Pixar Ouster, John Lasseter Returns With Apple and ‘Luck’
SUMMARY: John Lasseter was toppled five years ago by allegations about his workplace behavior. He’s back with an animated film and a studio that could be Pixar 2.0.

TITLE: Wells Fargo Revives Policy That Led to Fake Job Interviews, With Tweaks
SUMMARY: The bank will reinstate a requirement to assemble a “diverse slate” of job candidates while adding flexibility, according to an internal memo.

TITLE: What Remote Work Debate? They’ve Been Back at the Office for a While.
SUMMARY: Cubicles are largely empty in downtown San Francisco and midtown Manhattan, but workers in America’s midsize and small cities are back to their commutes.

TITLE: Judge Refuses Visa’s Request to Escape Pornhub-Related Lawsuit
SUMMARY: Visa faces questions about whether it enabled a porn site to profit from images of child sexual abuse, and both Mastercard and Visa face a new antitrust suit from Disney.

TITLE: Who’s to Blame for a Factory Shutdown: A Company, or California?
SUMMARY: The closing of a meatpacking plant near downtown Los Angeles has left its workers reeling and amplified questions about doing business in the state.

TITLE: As Russia Threatens Europe’s Energy, Ukraine Braces for a Hard Winter
SUMMARY: “Our goal is survival,” says the mayor of Lviv, as residents stockpile timber and ironworkers churn out wood-burning stoves.

TITLE: Analysis Deems Biden’s Climate and Tax Bill Fiscally Responsible
SUMMARY: Despite Republican claims, the new legislation would be only a modest corporate tax increase, Congress’s Joint Committee on Taxation found.

TITLE: Profits Slump at CNN as Ratings Plummet
SUMMARY: The network is on a pace to drop below $1 billion in profit for the first time in years, according to people familiar with its operations, amid steep declines in TV viewership.

TITLE: The Crypto Market Crashed. They’re Still Buying Bitcoin.
SUMMARY: Hard-core Bitcoin evangelists are making the case that Bitcoin differs from the unstable crypto projects that sent the market into a tailspin.

TITLE: Job Openings Fell in June, Suggesting That the Labor Market Is Cooling
SUMMARY: Employers appear to be responding to rising interest rates and a slowing economy by reducing open positions.

TITLE: Forbes Explores Sale After SPAC Deal Collapses
SUMMARY: Forbes has tapped Citigroup to sell at a price of at least the $630 million valuation declared in its earlier process to go public through a blank-check company.

TITLE: Bernard Marson, a Catalyst for SoHo’s Renaissance, Dies at 91
SUMMARY: An architect and developer, he helped pioneer the neighborhood’s transition from manufacturing into lofts where artists could work and live.

TITLE: Twitter Subpoenas Musk’s Banks in Fight Over Acquisition.
SUMMARY: Twitter has sent out requests for information from the banks that are backing the billionaire’s purchase, which he is trying to walk away from.

TITLE: Doing the Math on the Inflation Reduction Act
SUMMARY: The bill involves at least $260 billion in spending over 10 years, with a focus on energy and climate, but it would raise taxes by more than that, a congressional analysis found.

TITLE: Uber Posts Record Revenue but Loses More Money From Investments
SUMMARY: Despite posting a loss, the company’s quarterly results exceeded analyst expectations as more drivers returned to the road.

TITLE: Living Side by Side, Ukrainian and Russian Sailors Are Tested by War
SUMMARY: Sailors are accustomed to not discussing politics at sea, but the war between the two countries has made that more difficult.

TITLE: Is Bio-Designed Collagen the Next Step in Animal Protein Replacement?
SUMMARY: One company believes the possibilities go beyond vegan “meat,” from faux leather to luxury skin-care products. But is there enough demand outside of food alternatives?

TITLE: BP Triples Profit, Earning $8.5 Billion Windfall
SUMMARY: The company’s $8.5 billion profit beat expectations, rounding out a series of bumper reports by the biggest Western oil companies.

TITLE: Breaking Nicotine’s Powerful Draw
SUMMARY: Millions of smokers could be forced to confront the agony of nicotine withdrawal as the F.D.A. weighs calling for a drastic reduction in the addictive lure of cigarettes.

TITLE: Mo Ostin, Music Powerhouse Who Put Artists First, Dies at 95
SUMMARY: At the helm of Warner Bros. Records from the 1960s into the ’90s, he worked closely with some of the most successful and influential performers of his era.

TITLE: Justice Department and Penguin Random House’s Spar Over Merger Has Begun
SUMMARY: The trial to decide whether the publishing giant may buy Simon & Schuster is a test of the Biden administration’s push to expand antitrust enforcement.

TITLE: ‘Team Molly’ Parents Sue E-Bike Company Over Daughter’s Death
SUMMARY: An online community offered support for Molly Steinsapir, a 12-year-old who experienced brain trauma in an accident last year. Her mother and father have filed suit against Rad Power Bikes.

TITLE: Opendoor to Pay $62 Million to Settle Claims of Deceptive Marketing
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Commission accused Opendoor of deceiving customers into offering their properties to the online platform for less than they would have made on the open market.

TITLE: To Slow World Hunger, It Will Take More Than Ukrainian Grain Exports
SUMMARY: The departure of a grain-filled vessel from Odesa was hailed as a victory against global hunger. But experts say the crisis is so big that no single advance can reverse it.

TITLE: From Pizza to Dip, Chips and Popcorn: Pickle Is Summer’s Big Flavor
SUMMARY: For people with a sweet-and-sour tooth, there’s never been a greater pick of pickle-flavored possibilities, thanks to pickle spice.

TITLE: The government’s lawsuit to block Penguin Random House buying Simon & Schuster goes to trial.
CNN Profits Are Down as Ratings Plummet
SUMMARY: The network is on a pace to drop below $1 billion in profit for the first time in years, according to people familiar with its operations, amid steep declines in TV viewership.

TITLE: A Fed Pivot? Not Yet, Policymakers Suggest, as Rapid Inflation Lingers.
SUMMARY: Stocks rose after the Federal Reserve’s recent meeting, with investors hoping the central bank would dial back rate increases. Not so soon, officials indicated on Tuesday.

TITLE: Twitter Subpoenas Musk’s Banks in Fight Over Acquisition
SUMMARY: Twitter has sent out requests for information from the banks that are backing the billionaire’s purchase, which he is trying to walk away from.

TITLE: Neon, Film Distributor of Indie Darlings Like ‘Parasite,’ Ponders Sale
SUMMARY: It has tapped the investment bank Raine to assess its options, on the heels of a megadeal for another independent distributor, A24.

TITLE: U.S. Bid to Cap Russian Oil Prices Draws Skepticism Over Enforcement
SUMMARY: The maritime insurance industry says policing oil transactions is not workable, raising questions about enforcement of a buyer’s cartel.

TITLE: Max Hollein Consolidates Roles as Met Museum’s Chief
SUMMARY: With his appointment, the museum shifts away from its two-pronged leadership structure.

TITLE: What Nancy Pelosi’s Taiwan Trip Means for Business
SUMMARY: More fallout may be ahead for businesses and investors from a visit that tested China’s appetite for confrontation.

TITLE: 4 iPhone and Android Tricks You May Not Know About
SUMMARY: Keeping up with new software features can be a chore, but here are a few tools from recent updates that may be useful — and potentially lifesaving.

TITLE: Germany Tells Russia’s Gazprom Its Turbine Is Ready for Pipeline
SUMMARY: Olaf Scholz showed off a refurbished turbine for the Nord Stream 1 pipeline that Russia has said is the reason it can’t send more gas to Germany.

TITLE: New York Times Reports a Gain of 180,000 Digital Subscribers
SUMMARY: Revenue from digital advertising fell slightly in the second quarter, but subscription revenue continued to rise sharply, the company said.

TITLE: Congress Is Giving Billions to the Chip Industry. Strings Are Attached.
SUMMARY: Industrial policy is back in Washington, as a vast semiconductor and science bill gives the government new sway over a strategic industry.

TITLE: OPEC Plus Members Agree to a Small Increase in Oil Production
SUMMARY: Politically, the paltry increase would appear to be a snub of President Biden, who went to Saudi Arabia seeking assurances from big producers that they would act to cool oil markets.

TITLE: Starbucks Reports Record Revenue, Driven Mostly by Gen Z’s Love of Iced Drinks
SUMMARY: The largest coffee chain in the world said it saw no signs that consumers were giving up their nitro cold brews or iced espressos, despite higher prices.

TITLE: Robinhood Lays Off 23 Percent of Its Staff, Blaming Crypto Meltdown
SUMMARY: The trading app that helped drive the meme stock frenzy announced staff cuts for the second time this year.

TITLE: Stephen King Testifies in Penguin Random House Merger Trial
SUMMARY: “Consolidation is bad for competition,” Mr. King said in the trial that will determine whether Penguin Random House may acquire Simon & Schuster.

TITLE: New York Times Names Matt Purdy Editor at Large
SUMMARY: He has helped guide many of the newsroom’s most ambitious projects in recent years.

TITLE: More Americans Are Going Hungry, and It Costs More to Feed Them
SUMMARY: The director of the nation’s largest network of food banks is seeing support dwindle as need rises: “You’re in the middle of a battle, and people are leaving the field.”

TITLE: When Home Is a Ferry Ship: An Influx From Ukraine Strains Europe
SUMMARY: Millions have fled Russia’s invasion, but where housing is expensive and scarce, countries like Estonia are paying shipping firms to offer refugees safe but tight quarters.

TITLE: Response to Pelosi’s Taiwan Visit Mocked on China’s Social Media
SUMMARY: Many users mocked the government for not taking military action to stop Nancy Pelosi’s Taiwan trip, saying it hadn’t lived up to its tough rhetoric.

TITLE: Biden Administration’s Bid to Cap Russia Oil Prices Faces Resistance
SUMMARY: The maritime insurance industry says policing oil transactions is not workable, raising questions about enforcement of a buyers’ cartel.

TITLE: The Bank of England Makes Biggest Interest Rates Increase in 27 Years
SUMMARY: Britain’s central bank presented a grim forecast of inflation hitting 13 percent and warned that a long recession could start later this year.

TITLE: WeWork posts a smaller loss as its office occupancy grows.
SUMMARY: The provider of flexible work space said its memberships grew 33 percent in the second quarter and its occupancy rate climbed to 72 percent.

TITLE: Transportation Dept. Proposes New Rule to Ease Air Travel Chaos for Passengers
SUMMARY: If a new federal policy goes into effect, Americans will have more recourse when airlines cancel or significantly delay flights.

TITLE: With 5 Missiles, China Sends Stark Signal to Japan and U.S. on Taiwan
SUMMARY: By firing into Japanese waters, Beijing is warning that both countries will become targets if they should come to the aid of Taiwan in any conflict.

SUMMARY: A self-taught designer, he started out selling necklaces on the streets of New York and battled stereotypes, racial and otherwise, throughout his career.

TITLE: ‘Head of Team Anywhere,’ and Other Job Titles for an Uncertain Time
SUMMARY: Hyper-specific and unconventional roles are opening up to match a professional landscape no one has seen before.

TITLE: U.S. Oil Prices Fall Below $90 a Barrel for the First Time Since February
SUMMARY: The drop, from $120 a barrel just two months ago, could be a sign that investors are worried about a global recession.

TITLE: Tesla Faces Pressure Campaign From Activist Shareholders
SUMMARY: The automaker’s annual meeting will include votes on several proposals, including one on discrimination and another on board independence, that are opposed by its chief executive, Elon Musk.

TITLE: French Lawmakers Set to Approve Inflation Relief Package
SUMMARY: The measures include a cap on rent increases and an extension of fuel subsidies.

TITLE: India Scraps Data Privacy Bill
SUMMARY: A number of lawyers and experts say measures to safeguard citizens online are badly needed, but the bill was criticized by both privacy advocates and tech companies.

TITLE: 5 Takeaways From the Bank of England’s Meeting
SUMMARY: The central bank raised rates for the sixth straight meeting and said a long U.K. economic downturn is possible.

TITLE: Meet the accountants who may become the new power brokers of taxes.
SUMMARY: The Financial Accounting Standards Board, a private organization run by a seven-member board, determines how quarterly and annual profits are calculated.

TITLE: Another subpoena blitz in Twitter vs. Musk.
SUMMARY: Elon Musk subpoenaed the banks advising Twitter in its deal, and Twitter sent subpoenas to several people close to Mr. Musk.

TITLE: Inflation Reduction Act’s corporate minimum tax deciders
SUMMARY: A climate and tax bill could give a lot of power to an organization called the Financial Accounting Standards Board.

TITLE: Germany’s conservative leaders push for nuclear power to stay on as the country breaks from Russian fuels.
SUMMARY: Nuclear power is contentious in Germany, but the country is also likely to be sharply affected by Europe’s efforts to wean itself off Russian fuel sources because of Moscow’s war in Ukraine.

TITLE: Japan, Once the World Leader in Microchips, Now Races to Catch Up
SUMMARY: As it reckons with supply chain vulnerabilities, the country is spending billions to revitalize domestic production and seeking to form a coalition with “like-minded” nations.

TITLE: How Heat Waves are Changing Tourism in Europe
SUMMARY: Shifts in travel patterns are likely to become more common in Europe, a region that climate researchers describe as a “hot spot” for severe summer heat.

TITLE: Walmart Layoffs to Target 200 Corporate Jobs
SUMMARY: The move comes a week after the company announced it was lowering its profit forecast as inflation was catching up with consumer spending.

TITLE: Richard Tait, Co-Inventor of the Board Game Cranium, Dies at 58
SUMMARY: His decidedly eclectic board game became a familiar part of American family life in the late 1990s and 2000s.

TITLE: Welcomed by Taiwan, Pelosi Leaves Rising Tensions With China in Her Wake
SUMMARY: In a high-stakes visit to Taiwan, Ms. Pelosi offered assurances of American support. Taiwan now faces the prospect of Chinese military drills that could violate what it says are its territorial waters.

TITLE: Lucid Motors Slashes Production Forecast, Blaming Supply Chain Chaos
SUMMARY: The maker of luxury electric cars that hopes to challenge Tesla struggled to get parts and build vehicles in the second quarter.

TITLE: The Humbling of Coinbase
SUMMARY: In just over a year, the United States’ largest cryptocurrency exchange went from a triumphant public offering to a “crypto winter” of cost cutting and layoffs.

TITLE: U.S. Job Growth Unexpectedly Soared in July: Live Updates
SUMMARY: The employment gains, which far surpassed expectations, show that the labor market is not slowing despite efforts by the Federal Reserve to cool the economy.

TITLE: What the 1980s Can Teach Us About Interest Rates and Inflation
SUMMARY: When inflation was soaring 40 years ago and the economy slowed, short-term investing was perilous. But people with patience and long horizons came out fine.

TITLE: Amtrak Rewarded Executives With Six-Figure Bonuses as Rail Service Struggled
SUMMARY: Most of the top leaders received bonuses above $200,000 in the last fiscal year, as Amtrak worked to recover from the coronavirus pandemic.

TITLE: Amazon to Buy Maker of the Roomba for $1.7 Billion
SUMMARY: The acquisition of iRobot Corp., maker of the robot vacuum, will add to Amazon’s roster of smart home devices, which includes the Alexa virtual assistant and Ring doorbells.

TITLE: Twitter Rebuts Musk’s Fraud Claim in Dispute Over Fake Accounts
SUMMARY: Twitter called the claims false and irrelevant in a high-profile legal fight over whether the billionaire can back out of a $44 billion deal to acquire the company.

TITLE: Dee Hock, Credit Card Visionary, Is Dead at 93
SUMMARY: As chief executive of Visa, he transformed a struggling company into a global powerhouse and the world’s leading credit card network.

TITLE: The Carried Interest Loophole Survives Another Political Battle
SUMMARY: The latest effort to narrow the preferential tax treatment used by private equity executives failed after Senator Kyrsten Sinema objected.

TITLE: Carried Interest Is Back in the Headlines. Why It’s Not Going Away.
SUMMARY: Changes demanded by Senator Kyrsten Sinema will preserve a tax loophole that Democrats have complained about for years.

TITLE: Is Biden Right About a Recession? The July Jobs Report Suggests Yes.
SUMMARY: But the unexpectedly strong employment growth reported for July also appeared to contradict forecasts that the economy was cooling off.

TITLE: Sinema’s Puzzling Defense of the Carried Interest Loophole
SUMMARY: Senator Kyrsten Sinema had one main request before she would support a key spending bill: Preserve a tax loophole that mainly benefits people in private equity.

TITLE: Why College Students May Need Renter’s Insurance
SUMMARY: The insurance can help pay for property damaged in a fire or stolen. And replacing clothes, furniture and electronic gadgets adds up.

TITLE: Spain Limits Air-Conditioning to Save Energy
SUMMARY: The country this week became the latest to announce restrictions, in part to promote energy efficiency but also to reduce consumption of Russian gas.

TITLE: How Americans Feel About the Job Market
SUMMARY: In a survey, most say that it is a good time to find work and that the labor market favors employees. They see little change ahead for at least six months.

TITLE: Jacques Pépin, in Search of Lost Cars and Cuisine
SUMMARY: Have France’s distinctive food and automobiles slipped in their cultural cachet? The celebrity chef and serial owner of French cars has opinions on the matter.

TITLE: Plug-In Hybrid Cars Gain Ground in Race With Electric Rivals
SUMMARY: There has been a surge in the sales of cars that can travel short distances on just electricity and have a gasoline engine for longer trips.

TITLE: Trial of Former Twitter Employee Accused of Spying Heads to Jury
SUMMARY: Prosecutors said the man had used his access to Twitter user accounts to spy for the government of Saudi Arabia. His lawyers said he had just been doing his job.

TITLE: Georges Briguet, Who Presided Over Le Périgord, Dies at 85
SUMMARY: The owner of a classic French restaurant in Manhattan for a half-century, he welcomed his well-heeled guests by name, offering them a serene urban oasis on the far East Side.

TITLE: A Large Object Landed on His Sheep Farm. It Came From Space.
SUMMARY: “It’s not something you see every day on a sheep farm,” a farmer said of the pieces of debris that wound up in rural Australia. They are thought to be from a SpaceX spacecraft.

TITLE: HBO Max and Discovery+ to Be Combined in 2023
SUMMARY: The company also said it would launch, next summer, a combined paid service that would reach 130 million subscribers by 2025.

TITLE: I.R.S. Says Funding Won’t Mean More Audits for Middle-Income Americans
SUMMARY: If it is given an additional $80 billion, the agency said, the money is expected to go toward efforts to crack down on wealthy tax evaders and to modernize its technology.

TITLE: Transportation Dept. Proposes Changes to Federal Policy on Flight Refunds
SUMMARY: If a new federal policy goes into effect, Americans will have more recourse when airlines cancel or significantly delay flights.

TITLE: How This Economic Moment Rewrites the Rules
SUMMARY: Jobs aplenty. Sizzling demand. If the United States is headed into a recession, it is taking an unusual route, with many markers of a boom.

TITLE: Why Alex Jones’s Trial Won’t Stop the Spread of Lies
SUMMARY: His success has inspired a new generation of conspiracy theorists, who have learned how to stay away from legal trouble.

TITLE: The Companies That Take Money Straight From Your Paycheck
SUMMARY: Some lenders and retailers have a pretty neat business model: You pay them before your wages ever hit your bank account. And sometimes they give you no choice.

TITLE: How Argentines Cope With Inflation That’s 64% and Rising
SUMMARY: With the world grappling with rising prices, a tour through Argentina reveals that years of inflation can give rise to a truly bizarre economy.

TITLE: Major Indiana Employers Criticize State’s New Abortion Law
SUMMARY: The drug company Eli Lilly said it “will be forced” to look outside the state for employment growth. The engine maker Cummins said the law will “impede our ability to attract and retain top talent.”

TITLE: With Surge in July, U.S. Recovers the Jobs Lost in the Pandemic
SUMMARY: The increase of 528,000 outstripped expectations, and the gains were spread widely across industries. The jobless rate fell to 3.5 percent.

TITLE: Good News on Jobs May Mean Bad News Later as Hiring Spree Defies Fed
SUMMARY: Employers hired rapidly and paid more in July, suggesting the Federal Reserve may have to remain aggressive in its effort to cool the economy.

TITLE: How a New Corporate Minimum Tax Could Reshape Business Investments
SUMMARY: With a new corporate minimum tax, Democrats would be adding complexity to an already byzantine tax system.

TITLE: Graywolf Press’s New Publisher is Looking for Talent in New Places
SUMMARY: Carmen Giménez, Graywolf’s new executive director, wants to search for writers where ever “people are talking or thinking, or being creative or having a voice.”

TITLE: California Regulator Accuses Tesla of Falsely Advertising Autopilot
SUMMARY: A state agency said the electric carmaker had misled the public in describing its driver-assistance service as autonomous.

TITLE: Clock Running Out on Antitrust Bill Targeting Big Tech
SUMMARY: A sweeping bill that would enact the strongest restrictions on Big Tech companies in the United States has been stalled in the Senate.

TITLE: Eli Lilly and Other Major Indiana Employers Criticize Abortion Ban
SUMMARY: The drug company Eli Lilly said it “will be forced” to look outside the state for employment growth. The engine maker Cummins said the law will “impede our ability to attract and retain top talent.”

TITLE: The Week in Business: Blistering Job Growth
SUMMARY: Elon Musk countersues Twitter. The Walt Disney Company’s bold subscriber ambitions may get a check in its quarterly earnings report. And the latest inflation number comes out.
